abstract.p: Polypropylene composites reinforced with jute fabrics (Hessian cloth) were fabricated by heat-press molding technique. Mechanical properties of the composites such as tensile strength, tensile modulus, bending strength, bending modulus and impact strength were measured with reference to fiber loading in polypropylene matrix. Jute fabrics were treated with potassium permanganate in oxalic acid media in order to investigate the oxidizing effect on the properties of the composites. Solutions of oxalic acid were prepared in water as 1.0–10.0% w/v, where percentage of potassium permanganate was maintained at 0.01% w/v. Among the treatments, potassium permanganate in 5.0% oxalic acid treated jute composite showed better mechanical performance. Thermogravimetric data of polypropylene, jute fabrics and composites showed that thermal degradation temperatures of composites shifted to higher temperature regions compared to polypropylene or jute fabrics. Treatment of jute fabrics improved the thermal stability of the composite. Degradation characteristics of the composites were studied in soil, water and simulated weathering conditions. Water uptake of the composites was also studied. Treated jute composites were found less degradable as well as less water sensible compared to control composite.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The growing environmental awareness and rising global waste problem prompt the development concepts of sustainability and reconsideration of renewable resources. Natural fibers are renewable and can be incinerated for energy recovery in an environment-friendly way. During handling fiber products cause a little concern in terms of health and safety. The use of natural fibers as reinforcing materials in polymer matrix composites provides positive environmental benefits with respect to ultimate disposability and best utilization of raw materials. In addition, they exhibit excellent mechanical properties, low density and are cheap. Natural fibers like jute, flax, hemp, coir and sisal have already been exploited as reinforcing material for various purposes such as in automotive, construction as well as in packaging industries.1–9 Among all the natural fibers, jute appears to be the most useful, economical and exhibits moderately higher mechanical properties. Jute is a commercially available fiber, which is cultivated almost exclusively in Bangladesh and India. It has high cellulose content and low microfibril angle which are the desirable properties of a fiber to be used as reinforcement in a polymer matrix.10,11

Jute fiber consists of three major chemical constituents such as cellulose, hemicellulose and lignin. Jute fiber is hydrophilic in nature as it contains strongly polarized hydroxyl groups and other oxygen-containing groups. The hemicelluloses are mainly responsible for hydrophilic character, but the accessible cellulose, noncrystalline cellulose and surface of crystalline cellulose also play major roles. This fiber, therefore, is inherently incompatible with hydrophobic thermoplastics, such as polyolefins. The major limitations of using jute fiber as reinforcements in such matrices include poor interfacial adhesion between polar-hydrophilic fiber and nonpolar hydrophobic matrix and difficulties in mixing due to poor wetting of the fiber with the matrix. This in turn would lead to composites with weak interface. So, a strong adhesion at the interface of two different phases is needed for an effective transfer of stress and load distribution throughout the interface. This situation leads to development of strategies for surface modification of natural fibers or polymer matrices. Many attempts such as physical and chemical treatments have been adopted to improve the interfacial adhesion. Khan et al.12 explored the role of potassium permanganate (KMnO4) and urea on mechanical and degradable properties of photocured coir (Cocos nucifera) fiber with 1,6-hexanediol diacrylate. Coir fiber treated with KMnO4 alone and together with 1,6-hexanediol diacrylate and urea produced improved mechanical properties. For better mechanical performances of jute-PP composite, jute fabrics (hessian cloth) were treated with KMnO4 solution in acetone of different concentrations and at different soaking times. Optimized KMnO4-treated jute fabrics were again treated with 2-hydroxyethyl methacrylate (HEMA) solution along with urea and promising improvement of mechanical properties of the composites was observed.13 Moharana et al.14 used KMnO4 as initiator on graft copolymerization of methyl methacrylate onto defatted jute fibers and found no improvement in the tensile properties of the fibers. Jute fabrics reinforced urethane-based thermoset composites along with optimized KMnO4 treatment improved fiber/matrix adhesion.15 Woven bamboo mats were chemically modified with maleic anhydride, permanganate, benzoyl chloride, benzyl chloride and used as reinforcements in epoxy and polyester matrices. The tensile strength and modulus of permanganate-treated bamboo polyester composite were found to be increased significantly.16 Various surface treatments such as alkali, isocyanate, stearic acid, peroxide, permanganate and acetylation were carried out on the sisal fibers to improve interfacial bonding with low-density polyethylene (LDPE).17,18 The treatments enhanced the tensile properties of the composites considerably, but to varying degrees. Paul et al.19 investigated the effect of KMnO4 on dynamic mechanical properties of banana fiber and polypropylene (PP) composite.

In all cases, KMnO4 (in acetone) initiates grafting of Mn3+ ion onto the fibers, which increases the fiber/matrix adhesion. On the other hand, KMnO4 in acid and alkali media acts as an oxidizing agent. As the structural unit of cellulose contains three hydroxyl groups, one primary and two secondary, it undergoes chemical reactions typical of hydroxyl groups. The susceptibility of cellulose to oxidizing media depends upon the nature of the oxidizing agents and the conditions applied. The rate of formation of oxidized cellulose is also influenced by temperature, concentration of oxidant and the nature of the oxidizing agent itself. Oxidation promotes roughness of fiber surface and causes brittleness in fibers depending on the nature and strength of the oxidizing agent. The primary oxidized products of cellulose (aldehyde, ketone and carboxyl group at C-6 position of cellulose unit) can be further oxidized to dialdehyde by scission of bond between C2 and C3, which can again transform into carboxyl groups depending on the strength of the oxidants and reaction time. Thus, various oxidized products can be formed during oxidation of cellulose with oxidizing agents.20,21

The present research work deals with the treatment of jute fabrics with KMnO4 in oxalic acid (OA) medium as oxidizing agent. PP is used as a matrix material. The prime objective of this work is to study the effect of KMnO4 on mechanical and thermal properties of jute fabrics and its composites. The investigation also involves in determining the degradation characteristics and water uptake of the composites.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: Jute fabrics (Hessian cloth) were supplied by SADAT Textile Industries Ltd., Dhaka, Bangladesh. Average area weight of each sheet of jute fabric is 223.72 g/m2. KMnO4, OA and PP pellets (trade name: Cosmoplene) were procured from Merck, Germany, and the Polyolefin Company (Singapore) Pte. Ltd., respectively. The materials were used as received.

sec.title: Surface modification of jute fabrics
sec.p: OA solutions of different concentrations (1.0–10.0 %w/v) were prepared in distilled water. In these solutions, concentration of KMnO4 was maintained 0.01 %w/v. Jute fabrics were soaked with these solutions for 2 min at room temperature. The soaked jute fabrics were washed with running tap water for about 30 min to remove the unbound oxidizing agent. After soaking, jute fabrics were dried in an oven at 105°C for 6 h and then kept in a desiccator.

sec.title: Fabrication of composites
sec.p: PP sheets of desired size (15 cm × 13 cm) were prepared by compressing PP granules in the heat press (Carver, INC, USA, model 3856) at 190°C for 5 min under 5 tons pressure. PP sheets of different thicknesses were used for fabrication of the composites of different weight fraction of jute fabrics. Average area weight of each PP sheet for control composite is 237.66 g/m2. Jute fabrics were cut into small pieces of 15 cm × 13 cm size. Before composite fabrication, jute fabrics were dried in an oven at 105°C for 6 h and then kept in a desiccator. For composite fabrication, sandwich was made by alternately placing four layers of pre-weighed jute fabrics inside five layers of PP sheets. The sandwich was then placed between two steel plates with a composite fabrication mold which maintains the thickness of composite about 2 mm. The sandwich with this arrangement was compressed in the heat press at the same conditions which were applied for PP sheets preparation. After being heat pressed, PP sheets and composites were cooled to another press (Carver: model 4128) operated at cooling mode.

sec.title: Mechanical testing
sec.p: Tensile test of composite samples was carried out by a universal testing machine using a gauge length of 20 mm and cross-head speed of 2 mm/min. Three-point bending strength of the composite samples was measured in the same machine with a span length of 58 mm and cross-head speed of 2 mm/min. The tests were carried out according to DIN 53455 and DIN 53452 standard methods, respectively. Impact strength (Charpy) of the composites and PP was carried out in an impact tester (MT-3016, Pendulum type, Germany) following ASTM D 6110-97. All the results were taken as the average value of five samples.

sec.title: Thermal analysis
sec.p: Thermogravimetric and differential thermal analyzer (TG/DTA 6300, USA) have been used to simultaneously perform TG and DTA measurements. Temperature was maintained at the range of 30 to 600°C with a heating rate of 20°C/min in a nitrogen (purged at 100 ml/min) environment.

sec.title: Water uptake
sec.p: Specimens (60 mm × 15 mm × 2 mm) of the composites (control and treated) were immersed in the static water of glass beaker at room temperature for different time periods (up to 30 days). Before immersion, weight of the samples was taken. At certain time intervals, samples were taken out from the beaker and wiped smoothly with tissue paper and then weighed immediately. Percent water uptake was then calculated.

sec.title: Water degradation test
sec.p: Composite samples were completely immersed into the static water glass beaker at room temperature for a period of 30 days. At certain time interval, samples were taken out of water and dried in an oven at 105°C until the samples reached a constant weight and kept at room temperature for at least 24 h. Mechanical properties of the composites were then measured.

sec.title: Soil degradation test
sec.p: The composite samples were buried in soil at about 6 inches depth for different periods of time. After a certain period, samples were taken out carefully and washed with tap water to remove the soil particles from the surface of the specimens. Samples were then dried in an oven at 105°C until the samples reached a constant weight and kept at room temperature for at least 24 h. Mechanical properties of the samples were then measured.

sec.title: Simulated weathering test
sec.p: Specimens of composite (60 × 15 × 2 mm3) were exposed for aging in simulated weather to an Accelerated weathering tester (model Q.U.V, the Q- Panel Company, USA). The test was carried out with alternating cycles of sunshine over 4 h (65 ± 2°C) and dews and condensation for 2 h (45°C ± 2°C). This treatment was carried out for a maximum period of 600 h.

sec.title: Effect of fiber content
sec.p:
Incorporation of jute fabric in PP matrix greatly influences the mechanical properties of the composites. Tensile strength (TS), bending strength (BS), tensile modulus (TM), bending modulus (BM) and elongation at break (Eb) of the composites were measured as a function of jute content. Jute content in the composites varied from 28 to 52% by weight. It is clear from Table 1 that weight fraction of jute fabrics in composite up to 45% results in the increase of strengths and moduli of the composites. Further addition of jute fabrics (such as 50% fiber content) causes a reduction in strengths and moduli. So, the highest TS, BS, TM and BM of the composite were found for 45% wt. of fiber content. The highest values of the mechanical properties of composites at 45% fiber content may be explained in terms of orientation and homogeneity of fibers within matrix. At this stage, fibers get maximum level of orientation and mixed homogeneously within the matrix. As a result, when load is applied, stress is uniformly distributed among the fibers; hence, mechanical properties of the composites increase. At lower fiber content (such as 35% jute content), poor mechanical properties of the composites are attributed to nonhomogeneous fiber-matrix interaction. This results in low load transfer capacity among the fibers. As a consequence, stress gets accumulated at certain points of the composite and strains are also found highly localized in the matrix.22 But at high level of jute contents (such as 52% jute content), fibers get agglomerated within the matrix which causes nonuniform stress transfer. Also, too many fiber ends promote microcrack formation in the interface. As a result, strength and moduli of the composite again decrease.22,23

Eb of the composite is found to be decreased gradually as jute content increases. It is generally believed that elongation decreases with the increase of moduli of the composites.24 It is notable that, after 45% fiber content, the value of Eb is further reduced with the decrease of strength and moduli of the composite. It may be explained that jute fiber has much lower value of Eb than that of PP matrix and nonhomogeneity of interfacial adhesion predominates gradually with increase of fiber content. Furthermore, the formation of microcracks at higher fiber content might have been responsible for the reduction of Eb. So, at first, up to optimum fiber content, modulus is likely to play the key role for the reduction of Eb. Secondly, above the optimum level, decrease of Eb is mainly guided by the higher fiber content.

sec.title: Mechanical properties of the treated jute–PP composites
sec.p:
Composites prepared with KMnO4-treated jute fabrics in OA medium are denoted here as “CKM(OA)” and jute fabrics as “JKM(OA)”. The effect of KMnO4 in OA medium on TS and BS of the composites is presented in Figure 1. It is observed that TS and BS increase up to 5.0% OA treatment after that there is a decrease in strengths. The similar behavior is also recorded for TM and BM of the treated samples (Figure 2). It is observed that all the mechanical parameters achieve the highest values for 5.0% CKM(OA). TS of the treated composite (5.0% CKM(OA)) increases from 52 to 69.8 MPa, which is 34.2% higher than that of the control composite, and BS increases from 63.0 to 80.2 MPa, which shows 27.3% improvement. On the other hand, TM and BM increase to 24.27% (from 1.03 to 1.28 GPa) and 45.3% (from 3.27 to 4.75 GPa), respectively, than that of the control composite. Figure 1.
Effect of potassium permanganate (in oxalic acid [OA]) on tensile and bending strength of the composite. Figure 2.
Effect of potassium permanganate (in oxalic acid [OA]) on tensile and bending modulus of the composite.

The effect of KMnO4 (in OA) on impact strength (IS) of the composites is presented in Figure 3. The value of IS moves from 19.1 kJ/m2 (for control sample) to 24.4 kJ/m2. This value indicates 27.7% improvement over the IS value of control sample. Elongation at break of the treated samples is depicted in Figure 4. It is observed that with increasing concentrations of OA solution, Eb decreases gradually. Figure 3.
Effect of potassium permanganate (in oxalic acid [OA]) on impact strength of the composite. Figure 4.
Effect of potassium permanganate (in oxalic acid [OA]) on elongation at break of the composite.

The changes in mechanical properties of the treated composites may be explained on the basis of oxidizing effect of KMnO4 in OA medium onto jute fabrics. During oxidation, many changes happen into the cellulosic materials. The chemical and physical properties of the oxidized celluloses depend upon the nature of the oxidizing agents, oxidizing medium and the conditions applied. The rate of formation of oxidized cellulose is influenced by the concentration of oxidant, and the nature of the oxidizing agent itself. The rate of oxidation of the cellulose may be greatly accelerated by the simultaneous oxidation of a third substance in the system. When cellulose is treated with potassium dichromate and OA, both the OA and the cellulose are oxidized and the oxidation of the latter takes place much more rapidly than when cellulose is treated with potassium dichromate and sulphuric acid. Oxycelluloses of the extreme reducing type are conveniently prepared by treatment with potassium dichromate and OA. During oxidation cellulosic materials may undergo the attack on the surface of the crystallites which causes roughness of the fibers. On the severity of the action, the penetration into the amorphous and crystalline areas may also occur that degrades the fiberous materials.20,21,25 So, at lower concentrations of OA treatment (up to 5.0%), it can be assumed that the oxidized jute fabrics experience surface roughness and a reduction in compactness of the fiber bundles, which enhance effective surface area available for contact with the matrix. The additional sites of mechanical interlocking promote more interpenetration between fibers and PP matrix. As a result, mechanical properties of the composites increase upon treatment of jute fabrics with KMnO4 at lower concentrations of OA. At higher concentrations (such as 8.0% OA), KMnO4 may penetrate and attack into the amorphous regions and some of the crystalline regions that may degrade the fiberous materials. This morphological change causes agglomeration of fibers in the matrix or inhomogeneous stress transfer when load is applied. This resulted poor mechanical properties in the composites.

sec.title: Thermal properties of PP, untreated and treated jute fabrics and composites
sec.p: Thermogravimetric as well as differential thermal analyses were performed to study the thermal behavior of PP and both untreated and treated jute fabrics and composites. Fiber content in both untreated and treated composites was maintained at about 45% by weight. For exhibiting better mechanical performance, thermal investigations of the treated samples were carried out only for 5.0% JKM(OA) and 5.0% CKM(OA).

sec.title: Polypropylene
sec.p:
The thermal behavior of PP is shown in Figure 5. It is observed from DTG thermogram that a broad single peak starts around 371.6°C with a maximum degradation at 413.8°C at the rate of 1.634 mg/min. This peak corresponds to the rupture of C−C chain bonds along with H- abstraction at the site of rupture.26,27 PP is strongly hydrophobic (moisture content is 0%) in nature and totally decomposed at 426.8°C without formation of any char residue (TG thermogram). The DTA thermogram of PP shows the melting temperature of PP at 163.9°C. Figure 5.
Thermograms of polypropylene (PP).

sec.title: Jute fabrics
sec.p:
Figure 6 shows the major changes occurred in jute fabrics during thermal investigations. From TG thermograms it is observed that loss of moisture from the fabrics occurred below 100°C. The loss of moisture of untreated jute fabrics (a) and 5.0% JKM(OA) (b) was found to be 4.5 and 5.1%, respectively. Jute fiber is hydrophilic in nature, so it absorbs moisture from the atmosphere which is released during thermal treatment. The decomposition of hemicelluloses from untreated jute fabrics and 5.0% JKM(OA) starts at 296 and 298.4°C with the rate of 0.390 and 0.85 mg/min, respectively. The similar observation was also recorded for untreated jute fibers in the previous literature.26 Figure 6.
Thermograms of (a) untreated jute fabric and (b) 5.0% JKM(OA) (top–thermogravimetric (TG), middle–differential thermal analyzer (DTA), bottom–DTG).

The strong third peak observed at 365.0°C (rate 1.781 mg/min) and 362.8°C (1.6 mg/min) for untreated jute fabrics and 5.0% JKM(OA), respectively, may be attributed to the decomposition of α-cellulose. TG thermogram also shows that untreated jute fabric produces 20.7% char residues at 377.8°C. On the other hand, 5.0% JKM(OA) produces 18.2% char residues at 377.0°C. Char formation may involve initial physical desorption of water, intramolecular dehydration, formation of carboxyl and carbon-carbon double bonds, cleavage of glycosidic linkage and rupture of C–O and C–C bonds and condensation and aromatization of carbon atoms from each original pyranose ring to form discrete graphite layers.23,26,28,29 The above investigation like previous observation23,26 explores that compared to PP, jute fabrics are less thermally stable in nitrogen atmosphere.

sec.title: Composites
sec.p:
Thermograms of control composite (a) and 5.0% CKM(OA) (b) are displayed in Figure 7. In composite, two stage degradations occur first stage is responsible for jute fabric and second stage is for PP. TG thermograms show that loss of adsorbed water from control composite and 5.0% CKM(OA) is 1.9 and 1.8%, respectively. It is thought that during processing or testing, water could have been absorbed from the atmosphere if the fibers were not fully wetted by the matrix in the composite.30 Figure 7.
Thermograms of (a) control composite and (b) 5.0% CKM(OA) (top–thermogravimetric (TG), middle-differential thermal analyzer (DTA), bottom–DTG).

The DTG thermogram shows that maximum degradation temperature (MDT) of control composite for first and second stage is 365.1°C and 426.7°C, respectively. From these observations, it can be realized that MDT of untreated (365.0°C) jute fabric remains almost unchanged in the composite (365.1°C). At second stage, MDT of neat PP (413.8°C) is shifted to higher temperature regions by 12.9°C in the composite (426.7°C). It indicates that composite is more thermally stable compared to PP. MDT of 5.0% CKM(OA) for first and second stage is 362.6°C and 455.8°C, respectively. From this observation, it can be realized that the MDT of 5.0% JKM(OA) (362.8°C) remains almost unchanged in the composites. MDT of neat PP is shifted to higher temperature region in 5.0% CKM(OA) by 42.0°C. This means that treated composite is more thermally stable (by 29.1°C) than control composite. The residues obtained for control composite and 5.0% CKM(OA) are 9.4 and 5.2% at 438.6 and 467.6°C, respectively (TG thermogram).

sec.title: Comparison
sec.p:
Thermal stability of raw jute fabric was compared with the treated jute fabrics. The similar study was also carried out for control and treated composites. Comparing the onset, 50% and MDTs (Table 2), the order of thermal stability of raw and KMnO4-treated jute fabrics in OA medium can be stated as: 5.0% JKM(OA) < Raw jute fabric. Table 3 shows the comparative thermal stability of control and KMnO4 in OA-treated jute fabrics-PP composites and the order of thermal stability is control <5.0% CKM(OA). Better fiber-matrix adhesion may be responsible for the improved thermal stability of the treated jute-PP composite. Table 2.

sec.title: Water uptake
sec.p:
The percent water uptake of the control and KMnO4-treated jute fabrics-PP composites was measured with different time intervals (days). The results are presented in Figure 8. It is observed that water absorption of control composite is higher than that of the KMnO4-treated jute composites. The percent water gain of control composite is found to be 8.0–13% during the experimental periods, which drops down to 6.8–10.2% for 5.0% CKM(OA), respectively. In treated composite, the better fiber-matrix adhesion might be responsible for the lower tendency of water uptake compared to the control composite. It is also mentionable that during the period of 24 h, water absorption for both untreated and treated composites is very rapid. After 20 days of water soaking, percent water gain of control composite remains almost static. This phenomenon is observed after 10 days of soaking of 5.0% CKM(OA), respectively. At static conditions, fibers get saturated with water molecules and can no more gain water from the surroundings. Figure 8.
Percentage water uptake of the control composite and 5.0% CKM(OA) versus soaking time (days).

sec.title: Degradation studies
sec.p:
Degradation in water. Both control and KMnO4 in 5.0% OA-treated jute fabrics-PP composite samples were immersed in the water of glass beaker at room temperature for maximum period of 30 days in order to study the effect of such environmental condition on the degradability of the sample. The loss of tensile and bending properties of the treated and untreated composite samples was periodically measured with respect to their degradation time and the results are shown in Table 4. It is found that the loss of mechanical properties of the composites increases with the increase of degradation time. But the loss is higher for untreated sample than that of the treated samples. The loss of TS, BS, TM and BM of the untreated sample within the maximum period of observation is about 16.5, 15.0, 12.4 and 11.6%. The loss of TS and BS for 5.0% CKM(OA) is 12.6 and 11.9%, respectively. The similar trend is also recorded for the modulus of the composite. The loss of TM and BM is found to be 10.3 and 10.0%, respectively. Due to better interfacial adhesion, treated jute composites retain much of its properties under water aging condition. During water aging, water diffuses through the cutting edges of the samples and micro-organisms may attack into the jute fibers. Degradation in soil. Both untreated and KMnO4-treated jute fabrics-PP composite samples were buried in soil (at least 25% moisture) for up to 30 days in order to study the effect of such an environmental condition on the degradability of the samples. The loss of tensile and bending properties of the treated and control composite samples was periodically measured with respect to their degradation time and the results are shown in Table 5. It is found that for control and treated composites, both loss of tensile and bending properties increase gradually with increasing time of soil burial. After 30 days of soil degradation, the loss of TS, BS, TM and BM for control composite is about 25.6, 23.4, 18.4 and 17.5%, respectively. The loss of TS, BS, TM and BM observed for 5.0% CKM(OA) is 17.0, 16.5, 13.7 and 12.8%, respectively. This is clear that treated composite retains much of its mechanical properties than that of the untreated composite during soil degradation. Jute is a natural biodegradable fiber and has a strong tendency to degrade when it is buried in soil.33 Table 5.

sec.title: Simulated weathering effect
sec.p:
The loss of tensile and bending properties of the samples due to weathering is represented in Table 6. The experiment reveals that the reduction in tensile and bending properties of the composites due to weathering increases gradually with increasing exposure time. The loss of TS, BS, TM and BM of the control composite within the maximum period of observation is about 36.5, 33.0, 31.8 and 29.6%, respectively. On the other hand, the loss of TS, BS, TM and BM observed for 5.0% CKM(OA) is 25.9, 25.0, 22.7 and 22.0%, respectively. During simulating weathering experiment, the degradation effect is more pronounced in control composite than that of the treated composite. Due to UV exposure under the environmental conditions in the weathering, tester may be responsible for the loss of the mechanical properties of the composites. During weathering, leaching of lignin and water soluble products from the samples34,35 as well as absorption of water during the water spray and condensation cycle can occur. It is observed that both strength and modulus decrease with increasing duration of weathering. The reduction of strength and modulus could be due to degradation of fiber and fiber–matrix interfacial bonding. The most likely oxidation reaction36 is caused by UV radiation where O2 is used up before it can diffuse to the interior. The degradation is concentrated near the surface, even in fibers in which high UV levels are present in the interior. The photo-oxidation process also takes place mainly in amorphous regions because of their higher permeability to O2.36–38 The properties of the composite are also likely to have been affected by embrittlement of the matrix. During weathering, chain scission of PP36 occurred along with formation of surface cracks results in embrittlement of matrix.36,37 Thus, leaching of lignin/water soluble products, absorption of water in particular at the interface and embrittlement of PP can occur simultaneously during weathering,39 which might have caused reduction in the strength and modulus of the composites. sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The mechanical and thermal behavior of jute fabric/PP composites was studied with special reference to fiber content and fiber treatment. The mechanical properties of the untreated composites were found highest at 45% fiber content. Treatment of jute fiber with KMnO4 in OA medium brought an important change in the properties of the composites. Thermal analytical data showed that thermal stability of the composites either treated or untreated was higher than that of PP or jute fabrics. Treatment of jute fabrics increases the thermal stability of the composite. Treated jute composites exhibited lower tendency of water uptake compared to control composite. For better fiber–matrix adhesion, KMnO4 (in optimized OA concentration)-treated jute composites retained much of its mechanical properties in different environmental conditions compared to control composite.
